item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Biden Concludes Israel Trip as Protests Spread Over Gaza Hospital Blast
item.description: The president said he had convinced Egypt to allow 20 truckloads of aid into Gaza. Biden earlier said U.S. intelligence supported Israel’s claim that the blast was caused by a rocket fired from Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: With Putin by His Side, Xi Outlines His Vision of a New World Order
item.description: China’s close ties with Russia in countering American dominance point to a geopolitical rift that could shape the conflict between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Tiffany May
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, left, meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in Beijing, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Visits Israel and Putin Visits China Amid Gaza and Ukraine Wars
item.description: Washington’s strong support for Israel against Hamas is contrasted with Russian and Chinese efforts to align with the Palestinian struggle.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Israel on Wednesday to show solidarity with Washington’s close ally in the Middle East.

item.title: Putin Plays Down Threat Posed by Powerful U.S.-Supplied Missiles
item.description: Analysts say the long-range weapons could force Russia to move military assets further away from the front lines, undermining their operations.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Constant Méheut and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A residential building in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Wednesday after it was hit by a missile.

item.title: Liberia’s Presidential Election Goes to a Runoff
item.description: George Weah, a former soccer star who has been president since 2018, ran neck and neck with his main opponent in a rematch of the West African country’s last such contest.
item.dc:creator: Clair MacDougall and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Looking at newspaper headlines this past week in Monrovia, the Liberian capital. None of the candidates in the election drew the 50 percent needed for a first-round victory.

item.title: Fears of Violence Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon Grow
item.description: The fighting between Israel and Hamas has raised fears that the violence will spill into Lebanon as a wider conflict with Hezbollah. Such a war would be dangerous for all involved.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Shelling over Dahaira, a Lebanese border village, on Monday.

item.title: Rise of Fake Lawyers Rattles Kenya
item.description: The authorities are investigating numerous cases of unqualified people acting as lawyers. Some leaders in the country have voiced support for those caught in the act.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The Supreme Court of Kenya in Nairobi. At a time when the country is wrestling with rising inflation, skyrocketing fuel prices and tax hikes, Kenya is seeing a surge in the number of fake lawyers, officials say.

item.title: As Israel Ramps Up Gaza Airstrikes, Evacuees Say Nowhere Is Safe
item.description: Some Palestinians said they were considering returning to their homes in the northern Gaza Strip as strikes intensified in the south.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey, Monika Pronczuk and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: Poland’s Governing Party Looks Set to Be Ousted
item.description: An expected liberal coalition would probably reverse deeply conservative policies at home and diminish Poland’s role abroad as a beacon for right-wing groups.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Supporters of Third Way, a centrist alliance, celebrating in Warsaw on Sunday after an election was held.

item.title: A Severe Drought Pushes the Amazon Rainforest to the Brink
item.description: The rainforest holds a fifth of the world’s fresh water, but deforestation, dwindling rain and unrelenting heat are sucking it dry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: The Rio Negro, a tributary of the Amazon River, reached its lowest level ever recorded this week.

item.title: Russia Presses Ahead With Offensive Push in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: As winter approaches, Russian and Ukrainian forces are both trying to seize the initiative along different parts of the front.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading toward Avdiivka in eastern Ukraine, a focal point of the fighting.

item.title: Food Aid Sustains Quake-Hit Villages in Morocco, for Now
item.description: The earthquake that struck Morocco on Sept. 8 killed about 3,000 people and disrupted food supplies for thousands in regions long subject to the vagaries of fickle seasons.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami and Hannah Reyes Morales
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers for the World Central Kitchen are seen working in a field kitchen converted from an olive press processing plant as they prepare thousands of meals a day in Oulad Berhil to deploy to earthquake survivors in the high atlas mountain region in Morocco.

item.title: Police Kill Suspect in Brussels Terror Shooting, Official Says
item.description: The Tunisian man, who was shot dead by the police on Tuesday, killed two Swedish nationals, authorities said, calling it a terrorist act.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The scene of a shooting in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: India’s Top Court Rejects Gay Marriage, While Voicing Sympathy
item.description: Though it expanded the definition of discrimination, the ruling was a sharp setback for petitioners seeking a landmark victory on marriage equality.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Alex Travelli
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: India’s Supreme Court ruled that it was up to Parliament to approve same-sex marriage.

item.title: Families of Hamas Hostages Split on Possible Israeli Invasion of Gaza
item.description: The families are torn between wanting their loved ones returned safely at any cost and concern about more loss of life.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on a tank at a camp near Kibbutz Be’eri, Israel, on Tuesday. Israel has been massing forces around the Gaza Strip, in anticipation of a possible ground invasion of the enclave.

item.title: First Venezuelan Migrants Deported Under New U.S. Policy Arrive
item.description: The deportation of migrants who had entered the U.S. illegally came as the Biden administration lifted some sanctions against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Frances Robles
item.category: Chatham House (The Royal Institute of International Affairs)
item.media:credit: Veronica G. Cardenas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants boarding a plane in Harlingen, Texas, on Wednesday for deportation to Venezuela.

item.title: 300 Arrested on Capitol Hill in Call for Cease-Fire in Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Rallies over the Israel-Hamas war have continued to be held across the country and in world capitals.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters asked for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war, inside the Cannon House Office Building on Wednesday.

item.title: Jacob Lew, Biden Nominee for Ambassador to Israel, Is Grilled by Senators
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused Jacob Lew of having enabled the rise of Iran-backed terror groups as President Obama’s Treasury secretary.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew, President Biden’s nominee to serve as the next U.S. ambassador to Israel, attended a confirmation hearing with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Security Council Resolution on Israel-Hamas War
item.description: The American ambassador said the U.S. couldn’t support a measure that didn’t mention Israel’s right to self-defense.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Linda Thomas-Greenfield, right, the American ambassador to the United Nations, used the United States’ veto power to block a Security Council resolution on the Israel-Hamas war on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Says Israel Didn’t Cause Hospital Blast, as Biden Promises Aid to Gaza
item.description: President Biden backed Israel’s claim that a Gaza City explosion that killed hundreds, which Hamas blamed on Israel, had come from a failed rocket launch by an armed Palestinian group.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: People seeking help after heavy Israeli bombardment of Kahn Younis, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Protests Erupt Over ‘Horrific Scenes’ of Palestinians in Gaza
item.description: Not only Arabs in the street but, strikingly, also their rulers nearly uniformly condemned Israel for the Gaza hospital attack and other violence affecting Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with Lebanese Army soldiers near the United States Embassy in Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: Devastation in Gaza After Hospital Blast
item.description: Still reeling from an explosion outside Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, medical workers spoke of the destruction that left hundreds there dead. “We haven’t seen anything like this in our lives,” said one doctor.
item.dc:creator: Soliman Hijjy, Mark Boyer, Chevaz Clarke and Neil Collier
item.media:credit: Soliman Hijjy for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Biden Backs Israel on the Hospital Blast
item.description: Plus how much do we know about A.I.?
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden yesterday after meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Brings Tensions to Europe: What Travelers Need to Know
item.description: The intensifying war in the Middle East has led to demonstrations in London, Paris, Rome and beyond. Here’s what to expect amid the disruptions.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: Protesters light flares and wave flags during an unauthorized pro-Palestinian demonstration at the Place de la République in Paris last week.

item.title: Gaza Hospital Explosion: What We Know
item.description: Much is unclear about the strike that Palestinian authorities say killed hundreds.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The bodies of those killed in an explosion on Tuesday at the Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Why Is Gaza’s Rafah Border Crossing With Egypt So Important?
item.description: The access point, where aid trucks are waiting to enter from Egypt and people are waiting to leave, is the only land crossing into Gaza that is not controlled by Israel.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah border crossing between the Gaza Strip and Egypt on Monday. It is the only access point not controlled by Israel where civilians can enter and leave Gaza by land.

item.title: Humanitarian Aid for Gaza Amasses at Egypt’s Border as Crisis Worsens
item.description: Though the U.S. and Israel say they have cleared the way for the aid to make its way into Gaza, truckloads of supplies remain in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Mourad Hijazy
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks carrying aid was parked on the Egypt side of the Rafah border crossing with Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Early Intelligence Suggests Hospital Blast Caused by Palestinian Fighters, U.S. Says
item.description: U.S. officials cautioned that the analysis is preliminary and that the United States was continuing to collect and analyze evidence.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Patrick Kingsley, Helene Cooper and Adam Entous
item.media:description: A blast killed hundreds of people at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Scotland Braces For Heavy Rain and Winds From Storm Babet
item.description: Britain’s weather agency issued its highest alert for parts of Scotland, warning that as much as a month’s worth of rain is expected to fall between Thursday and Friday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Heavy rains earlier this month brought flooding to several parts of Scotland, including this sports field near Aviemore.

item.title: The Israeli military puts forward its version of what happened at the hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: People searching through debris outside the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza on Wednesday following a deadly blast there.

item.title: After Gaza Hospital Explosion, Bloody Blankets and ‘Lots of Bodies’
item.description: “We’ve never lived through a war this intense,” said a Palestinian journalist who captured the aftermath of the blast in Gaza that killed hundreds.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Hiba Yazbek and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion at the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City on Wednesday. Hundreds were killed, Gaza health authorities said.

item.title: Allied Spy Chiefs Warn of Chinese Espionage Targeting Tech Firms
item.description: F.B.I. officials say more than half of Chinese spying efforts aimed at stealing technology occurs in Silicon Valley.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: “We are dealing with another unprecedented threat,” said Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director. “There is no greater threat to innovation than the Chinese government.”

item.title: Biden Walks a Tightrope on Israel-Gaza as Democratic Tensions Smolder
item.description: The president has won bipartisan plaudits for his response to the war, and his trip to Israel offers a chance to appear statesmanlike. But anger on the left is growing as Israeli strikes pound Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: President Biden on his way to Israel. He has expressed firm support for the country after a Hamas attack that killed more than 1,400 Israelis.

item.title: Biden Tells Israel that Gaza Hospital Blast Appears to Be ‘Done By the Other Team’
item.description: In a rare wartime visit, President Biden paired his support for Israel with a plea not to let overwhelming grief or anger drive the country to go too far.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Hundreds of people have died in an explosion at a hospital in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinian civilians at the Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza on Tuesday. They were taken there after they were wounded in what Gaza officials said was an airstrike on the Ahli Arab Hospital.

item.title: Everton Sale Stalls Amid New Questions About 777 Partners
item.description: The U.S. firm bidding for the Premier League club, 777 Partners, has failed to provide required information to a British regulator.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: A sliding Everton player during a Premier League match against Tottenham in April. Everton’s finances are so dire that the club requires monthly infusions of millions of dollars to keep operating.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead in Gaza Hospital Blast as Israel and Hamas Blame Each Other
item.description: With President Biden about to arrive in Israel, Palestinians and Israelis blamed each other for the explosion that devastated the hospital, where people had sought shelter from Israeli bombing.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Hiba Yazbek
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: World Leaders Express Horror Over Deadly Gaza Hospital Blast
item.description: Expressions of horror over the large loss of life predominated, while many Arab governments stressed certainty that Israel was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Emergency responders delivering a civilian with injuries to a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden ‘Outraged’ Over Gaza Blast as He Makes a Wartime Visit to Israel
item.description: The explosion at a hospital highlights the dangers of a trip at a volatile moment in the war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Peter Baker
item.media:description: Palestinian civilians after a blast at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday. “We mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy,” President Biden said.

item.title: Venezuela Pledges Small Steps Toward Fair Elections Next Year
item.description: The agreement signed on Tuesday by the country’s authoritarian government and the opposition would not allow all candidates to run.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street market in Caracas in January. An economic crisis that has lasted for years has sparked a humanitarian crisis that has caused extensive migration.

item.title: U.S. Response to Israel-Hamas War Draws Fury in Mideast
item.description: The staunch support for Israel has stoked accusations of American hypocrisy, with Arab critics fearing a wholesale massacre of Palestinians in response to the deadly Hamas attack on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Alissa J. Rubin and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers around a mortar launcher firing toward Gaza from Be’eri, Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: What Is Islamic Jihad, the Group Israel Blamed for the Gaza Hospital Blast?
item.description: Like Hamas, the group receives support from Iran in funding and weapons.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Islamic Jihad supporters at a rally for the 35th anniversary of the group’s founding, in Gaza City last October.

item.title: Inside Biden’s Reversal on Sending Long-Range Missiles to Ukraine
item.description: The story is more complex than a caricature in Washington that President Biden is cautious to a fault, and says no until the pressure is insurmountable.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers during a training session in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: The Gaza hospital where hundreds were reported killed is a mainstay for Palestinians.
item.description: Hundre
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Palestinian midwives working in the maternity ward at Ahli Arab Hospital in 2019. At least 500 people were killed in an explosion at the hospital on Tuesday, Palestinian authorities said.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Blast Kills Hundreds at a Gaza Hospital
item.description: Plus the risks of iron deficiency for women.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Palestinian civilians after a blast struck a hospital in Gaza City.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Adds to Surge in Global Weapons Sales
item.description: Israel’s conflict with Hamas, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the rise of China have brought a boom for weapons makers and a chance for Washington to build closer military ties to other countries.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Bryan Birks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers building an F-15 fighter jet at a Boeing factory in St. Louis. Worldwide military spending hit $2.2 trillion last year.

item.title: Rescuers struggle as Israel’s bombardment buries Gazans in their homes.
item.description: The work of digging out some 1,200 people from destroyed buildings is too difficult and dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy injured by an Israeli airstrike receiving treatment at Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, in the Gaza Strip, on Tuesday.

item.title: CBC Radio Drops Its Daily Report of the Correct Time
item.description: After 84 years, changes in technology mean that CBC Radio will no longer broadcast the correct time once a day. Many Canadians are mourning the loss.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: The “long dash,” as the CBC’s daily announcement of the official time was known to generations of Canadians, was broadcast for the final time on Oct. 9.

item.title: U.S. Turns to Qatar for Hamas Hostages, Facing Risky Options in Gaza
item.description: Hamas is believed to hold at least 199 people in Gaza, a dense territory descending into a chaotic crisis, where many officials believe a military rescue would be dangerous for soldiers and hostages alike.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs of Israelis believed to have been kidnapped by Hamas on display near the Kirya, which houses the Israeli Ministry of Defense, in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Said to Use ATACMS, a Powerful Weapon System, for First Time
item.description: Ukrainian forces attacked two key Russian air bases behind enemy lines on Tuesday, using American-made long-range missiles known as ATACMS, a U.S. official said.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes, Marc Santora, Constant Méheut and John Ismay
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops using reconnaissance drones to search for Russian positions near Berdiansk, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Hamas Hijacked Victims’ Social Media Accounts to Spread Terror
item.description: The use of hostages’ Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp accounts to livestream attacks and issue death threats is a new tactic, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs of Israelis believed to have been kidnapped by Hamas on display near the Israeli Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv.

item.title: U.S. Tightens China’s Access to A.I. Chips
item.description: The further limits on shipments could cripple Beijing’s A.I. ambitions and dampen revenues for U.S. chip makers, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chips at Intel’s factory in Chandler, Ariz. Under new rules, U.S. companies can no longer supply advanced computing chips, chip-making equipment and other products to China without a special license.

item.title: Pentagon Orders 2,000 More U.S. Troops to Be Ready to Deploy to the Middle East
item.description: If deployed, they would likely not serve in combat roles but would provide advice and medical support to Israeli forces, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has extended the deployment of the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford and its accompanying warships, now in the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

item.title: U.S. Pursues Defense Partnership With India to Deter Chinese Aggression
item.description: Repairing American ships in Indian ports is a first step, as the U.S. military seeks to stretch out across the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shipyard on India’s southeastern coast where U.S. Navy ships have docked for repairs.

item.title: Palestinian Driver Is Thought to Be Hostage of Hamas
item.description: A 22-year-old is believed to be the only Palestinian who is not a citizen of Israel to be taken by Hamas in its recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a music festival in Israel that was overrun by Hamas militants this month.

item.title: Here’s the latest on the war.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden will go to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu extended an invitation to President Biden over the weekend.

item.title: France on Edge After Killing of a Teacher and Hamas Attack
item.description: Another attack at a school, three years after the beheading of a teacher, has heightened anxiety about a new wave of terrorism in an already scarred country.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Mourners gathering in Arras, France, on Sunday, two days after a teacher was killed in a knife attack at a public school in the city.

item.title: Netanyahu Opted for Limited Strikes in the Past. This Is His First All-Out War.
item.description: In his 15 years as Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu has been seen as risk-averse, avoiding open-ended military engagements and peace initiatives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday in Tel Aviv.
